Code Documentation¶

The following is documentation of generated from introspection of the code itself.

Clients¶

“No question is so difficult to answer as that to which the answer is obvious.” - Karl Bismark

Module contains classes that build clients to interact with the Pidman Application via services.

class pidservices.clients.PidmanRestClient(url, username='', password='')¶

Provides minimal REST client support for the pidmanager REST API. See that project documentation for details on the REST API. This class will build encapsulated calls to the Pidman Rest API service.

API calls that create, delete, or modify objects require valid credentials for a user with appropriate permissions. API calls are made using Basic Authorization, which base64 encodes username and password. It is recommended to use HTTPS for any REST API calls that require credentials.

Parameters:
  • baseurl – base url of the api for the pidman REST service., e.g. http://my.domain.com/pidserver
  • username – optional username for REST API access
  • password – optional password
absolute_url(path)¶

Prep an API URL for access based on base url.

create_ark(*args, **kwargs)¶

Convenience method to create a new ARK. See create_pid() for details and supported parameters.

create_domain(name, policy=None, parent=None)¶

Creates a POST request to the rest api with attributes to create a new domain.

Parameters:
  • name – label or title for the new Domain (unicode)
  • policy – policy title
  • parent – parent uri
create_pid(type, domain, target_uri, name=None, external_system=None, external_system_key=None, policy=None, proxy=None, qualifier=None)¶

POST a request to the REST api with the specified values to create a new pid with a single target.

Parameters:
  • type – type of pid to create (purl or ark)
  • domain – Domain new pid should belong to (specify by REST resource URI)
  • target_uri – URI the pid target should resolve to
  • name – name or identifier for the pid (unicode)
  • external_system – external system name
  • external_system_id – pid identifier in specified external system
  • policy – policy title
  • proxy – proxy name
  • qualifier – (ARK only) create a qualified target
Returns:

newly created ARK or PURL in resolvable form
Return type:

string
create_purl(*args, **kwargs)¶

Convenience method to create a new PURL. See create_pid() for details and supported parameters.

delete_ark_target(noid, qualifier='')¶

Delete an ARK target. (Delete is not supported for PURL targets.)

Parameters:
  • noid – noid identifier for the pid the target belongs to
  • qualifier – target qualifier; defaults to unqualified target
Returns:

True on successful deletion
get_ark(noid)¶

Convenience method to access information about an ark. See get_pid() for more details.

get_ark_target(noid, qualifier)¶

Convenience method to retrieve information about an ark target.

get_domain(domain_id)¶

Requests a domain by id.

Parameters:domain_id – ID of the domain to return.
get_pid(type, noid)¶

Get information about a single pid, identified by type and noid.

Parameters:
  • type – type of pid (ark or purl)
  • noid – noid identifier for the requested pid
Returns:

a dictionary of information about the requested pid
get_purl(noid)¶

Convenience method to access information about a purl. See get_pid() for more details.

get_purl_target(noid)¶

Convenience method to retrieve information about a purl target.

get_target(type, noid, qualifier='')¶

Get information about a single purl or ark target, identified by pid type, noid, and qualifier.

Parameters:
  • type – type of pid (ark or purl)
  • noid – noid identifier for the pid the target belongs to
  • qualifier – target qualifier - defaults to unqualified target
Returns:

a dictionary of information about the requested target
list_domains()¶

Returns the default domain list from the rest server.

search_pids(pid=None, type=None, target=None, domain=None, domain_uri=None, page=None, count=None)¶

Queries the PID search api and returns the data results.

Parameters:
  • domain – Exact domain name for pid
  • domain_uri – URI of a domain.
  • type – purl or ark
  • pid – Exact pid value
  • target – Exact target uri
  • page – Page number of results to return
  • count – Number of results to return on a single page.
update_ark(*args, **kwargs)¶

Convenience method to update an existing ark. See update_pid() for details and supported parameters.

update_ark_target(*args, **kwargs)¶

Convenience method to update a single existing ark target. See update_target() for details and supported parameters.

update_domain(domain_id, name=None, policy=None, parent=None)¶

Updates an existing domain with new information.

Parameters:
  • domain_id – ID of the domain to update
  • name – label or title for the domain
  • policy – policy title
  • parent – parent uri
update_pid(type, noid, domain=None, name=None, external_system=None, external_system_key=None, policy=None)¶

Update an existing pid with new information.

Parameters:
  • type – type of pid (purl or ark)
  • domain – Domain pid should belong to (specify by REST resource URI)
  • name – name or identifier for the pid
  • external_system – external system name
  • external_system_id – pid identifier in specified external system
  • policy – policy title
Returns:

a dictionary of information for the update pid
update_purl(*args, **kwargs)¶

Convenience method to update an existing purl. See update_pid() for details and supported parameters.

update_purl_target(noid, *args, **kwargs)¶

Convenience method to update a single existing purl target. See update_target() for details and supported parameters. Qualifier parameter should not be provided when using this method since a PURL may only have one, unqualified target.

update_target(type, noid, qualifier='', target_uri=None, proxy=None, active=None)¶

Update a single pid target.

This method can be used to add new targets to an existing ARK.

Parameters:
  • type – type of pid the target belongs to (purl or ark)
  • noid – noid identifier for the pid the target belongs to
  • qualifier – target qualifier; defaults to unqualified target
  • target_uri – URI the target should resolve to
  • proxy – name of the proxy that should be used to resolve the target
  • active – boolean, indicating whether the target should be considered active (inactive targets will not be resolved)
Returns:

dictionary of information about the updated target.
pidservices.clients.is_ark(str)¶

Check if a string matches a regular expression for an ARK, in either resolvable url form or short-form id, with or without qualifiers.

Parameters:str – string to check
Returns:re.MatchObject or None (can be treated as a boolean)
pidservices.clients.parse_ark(ark)¶

Parse an ARK into its component parts. Uses the same regular expression as is_ark(); matches both short and resolvable ARKs, with and without qualifiers.

Parameters:ark – ARK string to parse
Returns:dictionary with parsed ARK information or None if the regular expression does not match. Dictionary keys in the return:
  • nma - Name Mapping Authority (base url portion of resolvable ark)
  • naan - Name Assigning Authority Number
  • noid - Nice Opaque Identifier
  • qualifier - qualifier

Django Integration¶

“It turns out that an eerie type of chaos can lurk just behind a facade of order - and yet, deep inside the chaos lurks an even eerier type of order”

  • Douglas Hostadler

Provides a minimal Django wrapper for various pidman services to load various Django settings.

class pidservices.djangowrapper.shortcuts.DjangoPidmanRestClient¶

Wraps PidmanRestClient to use Pidman host and connection information from the Django settings file instead of having to define it in the class call.

NOTE: The following values MUST be added to your project’s django settings.py file for this class to work properly:

PIDMAN_HOST = '' # base url for the pidman server to query. e.g.,
    ``http://pid.emory.edu/``
PIDMAN_USER = '' # Username for authentication to the pidman app.
PIDMAN_PASSWORD = '' # Pasword for username above.

Convenience Methods¶

clients.is_ark(str)

Check if a string matches a regular expression for an ARK, in either resolvable url form or short-form id, with or without qualifiers.

Parameters:str – string to check
Returns:re.MatchObject or None (can be treated as a boolean)
clients.parse_ark(ark)

Parse an ARK into its component parts. Uses the same regular expression as is_ark(); matches both short and resolvable ARKs, with and without qualifiers.

Parameters:ark – ARK string to parse
Returns:dictionary with parsed ARK information or None if the regular expression does not match. Dictionary keys in the return:
  • nma - Name Mapping Authority (base url portion of resolvable ark)
  • naan - Name Assigning Authority Number
  • noid - Nice Opaque Identifier
  • qualifier - qualifier
